results.title: Ski bums
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Silva Basmajian and John Zaritsky
results.brief_description: Ski bums: Crucial Mike’s definition - “being able to participate in a rich man’s sport without the financial means to do it”. This is a fascinating documentary which explores the lives of ten “ski bums” in Whistler, British Columbia, where 2.2 million international tourists visit annually and also where 10,000 ski bums live permanently. It is a choice of lifestyle, of extreme skiing and snowboarding, pushing the limits, of living for the moment and not worrying about what tomorrow may bring. It is also a question of survival and just how resourceful a ski bum has to be to pursue their magnificent obsession. Obtaining free passes, skis, clothing, even food sometimes, becomes part of the daily routine. Most have some form of casual or part-time work, but finding accommodation can be quite challenging. The film combines anecdotal stories, past and present, by Crucial Mike, Punchy, Johnny Thrash, Luddy, Cupcake, Stray Doggy and others with spectacular action footage of them skiing or snowboarding the breathtakingly rugged snowcapped mountains. With some great cinematography and music backing, Oscar winning director, John Zaritsky (Just another missing kid, 1982) has produced a refreshingly honest and upfront look at these devotees of the mountains. WARNING: SOME SCENES CONTAIN NUDITY, DRUG USE AND COARSE LANGUAGE.

results.title: Skeletons in our closet
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: As each new generation makes its mark on the fabric of Australian society, inevitably changes in lifestyles and attitudes will occur. Throughout the 20th century, the motion picture camera has recorded these changes, creating a permanent, living record of our past. This program has been compiled from Cinesound and Movietone Newsreel items, as well as advertising films from the 1930s to the 1960s. As you watch this video, some of the stories will make you laugh, others you may find distasteful, a few will seem absurd, but most of them are certain to make you cringe. NOTE: Some of the footage in this video may contain material of a sexist or racist nature.

results.title: Skeletons aren't scary
results.creator_credit: Bosisto Productions, South Australian Film Corporation and John Dick

results.title: Sixty years of fashion
results.creator_credit: Basic Films, Leon Clore and Sam Napier-Bell
results.brief_description: A review of women’s fashions in Britain from 1900-1960, showing the influence of historical events and social changes, and the alterations which fluctuating fashions imposed on the shape of the female body. Shows opulent Edwardian ballgowns, tubular dresses of the 1920’s and elegant lines of the 1930’s, the utility outfits of the war years, and some of the 1950’s ready-to-wear clothing.

results.title: Sixty years later
results.brief_description: To mark the Australian visit of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II during the silver jubilee of her reign, Australia’s Navy, Army and Air Force combined to present a massed parade of personnel and colours in front of Parliament House, Canberra on 8 March 1977.

results.title: Sixteen days in September
results.brief_description: The September 2000 Olympic Games held in Sydney, Australia has been hailed as the Games that restored people’s faith in the Olympic movement. With a global participation of 11,000 athletes from 200 nations, this commemorative program captures all the greatest achievements and performances of Australia’s most successful Olympic team ever and shows all of their medal-winning performances, whether Gold, Silver or Bronze.

results.title: Sixteen candles
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Hilton Green and John Hughes
results.brief_description: John Hughes spirited teen comedy stars Molly Ringwald as Samantha Baker, an average teenage girl whose awkward trek through adolescence becomes unbearable when her parents forget her sixteenth birthday. To make matters worse the high school geek (Anthony Michael Hall) starts hitting on her while Samantha negotiates her own painful crush for the handsome but taken senior, Jake Ryan (Michael Schoeffling). Aside from some moments of broad slapstick and crass stereotypes, Hughes makes some pointed observations on the trials, rituals and tribulations of American teenagers and in the process created a teen icon out of his luminous lead Molly Ringwald. “Sixteen candles” was the beginning of a very lucrative career in teen movies for Hughes who cornered the market in the 80’s with such films as “The “Breakfast club”, “Pretty in pink” and “Ferris Buellers day off”. Cast also includes John Cusack, Justin Henry, Paul Dooley, Gedde Watanabe, Jami Gertz and Joan Cusack.

results.title: Six minutes with nature
results.brief_description: The life cycle of a butterfly known as “The Wanderer” showing the egg, caterpillar, eating, chrysalis and final emergence of the butterfly. This film won a special award for the best nature film in the Commonwealth Jubilee Film Competition.
